commentBody:
Nice job by Ginny TOO.

Or was it Ginny TWO?

Or was it Ginny TO?

Or was it Ginny TÚ?
Fitting that this was published just a few days after the brilliant finale of The Rehearsal with its hero Captain ALLEARS
Chewy.

When I worked in a public library many years ago, I never got a request for a book about a Scottish artist named McEscher, but I did get one from a mother helping her seventh grader out with a report for a book about a French artist who lived ca. 1890-1910 named Art Noview.
Crossing BLEH with LIPO is kinda .....
Nice theme, but BLEH around the edges.

Challenging for a Tuesday!  Fun theme that took some thinking, and it reminds me of my fifth grade teacher, who had a very memorable way of ensuring that we would never call our socks "holy" when they started to fall apart.  

BOLT down?  As someone who, ahem, eats at a pace that some would consider uncivilized, I am certainly familiar with WOLFING, SCARFING, or GULPING down your food.  Never heard of BOLTING it though.  (Please don't reply with a link showing its common usage, I already Googled it.) BLEH also tripped me up for a minute or two.
I’d be happy if I never see another non-descript sound like BLEH in a puzzle again. Seems like the lowest kind of filler.

"BOLT" down? Not so sure about that one.

I had "CHOW", which fit the space, and slowed me down for a bit.

Nice theme. 

Reminds me of the year I got small Jarlsbergs as a stocking filler:

Holey baby cheeses!

Delightful!

A few moony poems by Li Po.

STILL NIGHT THOUGHTS

Moonlight in front of my bed --
I took it for frost on the ground!
I lift my eyes to watch the mountain moon,
lower them and dream of home.

                                                        (Burton Watson, trans.)

MOUNTAIN DRINKING SONG

To drown the ancient sorrows,
we drank a hundred jugs of wine
there in the beautiful night.
We couldn't go to bed with the moon so bright.

The finally the wine overcame us
and we lay down on the empty mountain—
the earth for a pillow,
and a blanket made of heaven.

                                                     (Sam Hamill, trans.)

ZAZEN ON CHING-T'ING MOUNTAIN

The birds have vanished down the sky.
Now the last cloud drains away.

We sit together, the mountain and me,
until only the mountain remains.

                                                              (Hamill)

DRINKING ALONE UNDER THE MOON

I take my wine jug out among the flowers
to drink alone, without friends.

I raise my cup to entice the moon.
That, and my shadow, makes us three.

But the moon doesn't drink,
and my shadow silently follows.

I will travel with moon and shadow,
happy to the end of spring.

When I sing, the moon dances.
When I dance, my shadow dances, too.

We share life's joys when sober.
Drunk, each goes a separate way.

Constant friends, although we wander,
we'll meet again in the Milky Way.

                                                        (Hamill)

Haha. Almost got me. I had BLaH (which I was pretty confident with), no clue on LI_O, and was not seeing the alternate meaning of banner (that which bans). After running the alphabet on that square and getting nothing, and looking through the rest of the puzzle like 4 times and seeing nothing wrong, I eventually changed BLaH to BLEH and finally figured out what was going on.  I thought I was going to lose my 467 day streak on a Tuesday! I think my last streak break happened on a Wednesday. You’d think it would be a later-week puzzle that did me in, but sometimes there’s a section in an easier puzzle that just catches you.

This was awfully measly for a Monday puzzle.  BOLT stumped me, and aplenty several others.

I can't fund any reference to a Lake ERIE in the UK.  If the revenue is to London, Ontario, the Lake Erie is is a lot closer than 150 miles.

I'm scratching my head a bit here.

I would have liked to like this one, but there were three or four clues that soured up the whole puzzle. His name is Li Bai, not "Li Po." BLEH was a travesty. No one BOLTs down a meal. 

HOLE puzzle felt '90s in a good way, though.

HOLY smokes, this was crunchy, but it made for a WHOLLY terrific Tuesday. Thank you, Ginny Too! For those who were thinking I might post Bowie for some glam rock, the logic is fair but somewhat HOLEY. I give you Roxy Music instead: ;-) https://youtu.be/bpA_5a0miWk?si=p915g6G4N2pqUvv_
Ginny, I work in tax and I would have LOVED the GAAP clue :’) great puzzle!

Stealing a few minutes to work this puzzle.  It's our 55th anniversary, and even though we're not celebrating intensely, I'm glad the puzzle was not more difficult and is quickly done.

Thank you, Ginny Too.  It was worth coming for.
Interesting to see several people who'd never heard the word BOLT associated with eating food in a hurry. Must be a Midwest colloquialism.
LIPO/HOLI was a rare early week natick. Maybe a little too chewy for a Tuesday.
San Franciscans had a slight advantage today. LI PO: the legendary Chinatown watering hole, featured on the silver and small screens. https://youtu.be/im2GgJx_3NU?si=H23rE4__Flsci8ky
This was a Tuesday puzzle!? To that I say BLEH, whatever that means.

This was too hard for a Tuesday, IMO. I filled the grid in Wednesday time, and with one lookup.

I struggled in several places, especially around LIPO, whom I've never heard about (neither her/him or that book). I have no idea why duck-hunting hangout solves to BLIND (some help, please?), I wanted OHmy rather than OH NO, and "caaaar" completely stumped me (I only got it when crosses revealed it. The fact there are no stretch limos on European streets may be the reason. Audi A8L is the longest sort of car one sees around here). I only got out of this mess by looking up LIPO. I can only imagine how much more still I'd have been confused there had I not known about HOLI FESTIVAL and EPA.

BRIE clued as a spread confused me, too. I eat it like the French - I cut bits off and put them in my mouth. I've never literally spread a French cheese on anything in my life. I may sometimes go Polish and put it on bread, but I don't spread it even then. I've just read up on brie-eating in the US. You cut off the rind??? You spread it on *crackers*? Ye gods... I suppose I knew about the crackers things from a previous puzzle, but I must have repressed the factoid as very alien and slightly disturbing to me.

DEB made me shrug. Americans will shorten everything, won't they. Or was this just crosswordese, like RETOOLS and RETAG? Also, I wonder what Deb Amlen thought of this 🤣

The theme was OK, and it helped me solve. Still, I would have preferred this puzzle to run on Wednesday.

Whoo doggy! That was some Tuesday. Tough fill and Wednesday+ level cluing. 

Would be thrilled if they were all as chewy. I loved it.

Very surprised by all the objections to BLEH and BOLT, neither of which is new to me. If anything, I’d have expected protests over BRIE being referred to as a “gooey spread”. 

But no complaints here. As far as I’m concerned, any puzzle that features BADASSERY is fine by me!

Holy Cow* Ginny, you had me right off the bat with TOSCA, which coincidentally was on PBS this past weekend.

Another nicely Toughened Up Tuesday, which had me worried for a moment, because I did not know LI PO, and the tricky clue for EPA had me stymied for a bit.

And Patty Lupone will always be EVITA to me. 

*RIP Phil Rizzuto.
Hard for a Tuesday, but fun.

I really didn’t like this puzzle. Maybe I’m tired, but my first instinct was almost never correct, and I didn’t care for some of the cluing. I’m usually a 6-minute solver of Tuesday puzzles, and for some reason this one took me more than 11. It’s just a weird puzzle all around, in my opinion.
By the time I had decided that "at least one" of my problem(s) involved my BLAH and APA where 32D and 41A crossed and fixed it, I was 40 minutes older than ever. :-(

I was nearly stumped by CPA.  With my computer background, I assumed it was a CPU, which stands for central processing unit, the heart — probably better expressed as the brain — of a computer.  (North of the border — not a line drawn arbitrarily with a ruler, by the way — CA, standing for “chartered accountant”, was, until fairly recently, the term used here.) But that left me wondering what on earth (off earth?) a FUE is. Google told me that it stands for “follicle extraction unit”, a method for addressing baldness.  In conclusion, this was one hairy Tuesday puzzle.

This took me 10 minutes longer than my average! Tough Tuesday for me. I spent almost 5 minutes flyspecking for my error and had the exact same experience as @Jeb Jones. That intersection of BLEH/EPA/LIPO almost had me lose my 1,418 day streak! Phew 😮‍💨😅  
Thank you for this brain workout, Ginny! I appreciate a good challenge!

Thoroughly enjoyed save the BLIND BLEH situation on the left. A niche but if knowledge and dodgy spelling felt much more like Thursday territory. 
Great theme!
I dunno about that Brie clue. If its natural state is firm enough to cube, it really a spread?
Super lazy inclusion of yacht as a central down answer after yesterday’s use of its plural in a similar location.
One can also WOLF down food.

Interesting theme and some tough clues to get around. My only real comment is that I, like some, had absolutely no idea that the romanization of Li Bai is Li Po. That really threw me for a loop, especially considering he's such a staple of Chinese culture, and I grew up learning to recite his poems.
The H in HMS was actually less than half of the 20th century. But a nice puzzle
Bold puzzle in many ways, nicely done
100 DAY STREAK!!! 🎉🎉🎉🎉🎉🎉🎉🎉🎉🎉 Proud (and embarrassed) to say this is one of my finest accomplishments. Going for 365!
Brie is a spread? 👀

If you define BRIE as gooey spread, we must be eating very different cheese. 

This one unfortunately wasn’t for men on several accounts, too tough for a Tuesday and lacked charm.

Curious about all the negative reactions to BLEH — maybe it’s a regionalism? (It’s common in the Northeast, I think.) 

My big issue was the LIPO / EPA cross — I had to look it up. Both could have been clued differently to avoid that

CAAAAAAAR immediately brought to mind
playing stickball
in the street
on a warm summer day.

Two things we would look out for:
CAAAAAAARs
and the Pied Piper man.

He would hit the ball, and whoever caught it got a free ice cream.

Loved the theme and the memory.  Thanks, Ginny.

Great fun, especially  the almost pearl-clutching HOLEYCHEESES!

Hand up for the original G.A.A.P clue.
BADASSERY!  Nice.
With the French Open underway, one might enjoy the March 17, 2013 Sunday puzzle.

Kudos to Joel Fagliano, whose mini crosswords so often amaze me with their wit and surprise.  He takes command of that little box and transforms it into a gem, time after time, and once again, today.  Bravo, sir.

Challenging for a Tuesday. Barely beat my average.

I particularly enjoyed the clue for ERIE. There's more than one London in the world!

Thanks!

Caaaaaaaaar was awesome.

Reminded me of a Far Side cartoon.

Cows in a pasture, standing upright,
smoking cigarettes and drinking.

One yells, “Car!”

Second frame,  the car is diving by 
ans someone yells, “Cows!”
Cows are all back on all fours, chewing grass.

Happy Tuesday all!

Lordgodalmighty. 

Where was I? Oh yeah - a bit on the tough side for me, but ended up being an enjoyable Tuesday workout. Catching on to the theme was a big turning point and that's always a nice touch.

And, of course a puzzle find today. Pretty remarkable one - I'll put it in a reply. 

...

So there have many glitches with the comments recently, and a lot of discussion about them. I am curious-- --

Currently, I have a Games-only subscription to the NYT, although for a couple years (as a result of a promo), I have a full (digital) subscription. I assume that most, if not all, article-pages have a section on which readers can leave comments. My question is--are these glitches happening on all reader comment forums*, or just on Wordplay.

Of course, the comments on this forum serve a different purpose from many--sort of a club-house for like-minded persons, on which to gather and play that Glass Bead Game we call Wordplay. We swap stories, opinions, songs, even recipes! We have *conversations*. Sometimes we argue, but in general the tone is positive, at least towards one another. Political commentary is kept to a minimum, and, when expressed, usually veiled. Of the core group of regular posters, when someone ceases to post, their absence is noticed.

Does this sort of camaraderie happen on other articles or columns? I don't know, but I doubt it. So in that sense, we have different expectations from the NYT website than most readers.
Thanks for the perfect Tuesday puzzle! I too see absolutely no problem with BLEH and BOLT - there are a lot of armchair crossword constructors out there!
Just came here to say today’s MINI is just beautiful. Great job Joel.

Holy homophones, Batman!

And LI PO in his LIMO went LOCO.


BADASSERY EVITA went down.

About a minute faster than my average for a streak of 2277.

Only comment about the crossword, as others have mentioned, is that “fake” London, aka London, Ontario, Canada, is about 25 miles north of the shores of Lake ERIE and 75 miles from the southern shore. Perhaps the editor meant 120 km?

Still, the answers had to be BRIE/ERIE but it felt weird.

Difficult for a Tuesday but not in an enjoyable or thought-provoking way. Felt like the constructor was intentionally cluing for one word and then revealed to another in an attempt at being “clever”. Didn’t feel like a satisfying solve.

Ginny has wit.  She proved that in her last Times puzzle, a debut (Sunday 6/30/24), where her theme answers were hilarious, and it returned today, IMO, with three clues:
[Xing user], [DDT banner], and [Caaaaaaar, you might say].

Add a revealer that is a punchline (and how many times in your life have you heard HOLY TRINITY as a punchline?), a terrific NYT debut answer in ALL GOOD, an artist I adore (ESCHER), animal cuteness in CAT and STOAT, plus the sweet serendipity that CHEESES rhymes with a member of the Holy Trinity – and I was highly entertained.

This was a day lifter, Ginny, and thank you greatly for it.  I am so hoping for more from you!
This puzzle got lost on it’s way to a Thursday 🤔

good puzzle. it took me longer than the average Tuesday because there were some tough clues. I got hung up on "wholly owned" just didn't click -until it did. Couldn't figure out lake south of London until I read in the comments about the other London. Good one.
Never heard of Lipo. Didn't understand DDT Banner. Ok, now I do as I write this. Still, annoying.

Eh, it was kind of a yawner, but once the theme revealed itself, much interest was peaked.

Thankfully, the “?” after glam rock detracted me from Iggy, Mott or Kiss.

In my many years being a soldier, I've bolted to the mess hall to chow down, wolfed down some chow, then bolted out to formation., but never bolted down chow. 

Knowing these puzzles are constructed well before NYT releases them, how timely of the duck hunters clue, days after Phil Robertson’s passing. Uncle Si… hang in there, brother.

The caaaaaaar clue had me think of a Bostonian flair, but lose a few a’s and the “r”and maybe(?). That's kind of a stretch, and a wicked one, at that.

Ah, the ever popular stoat! Not familiar with that little weasel at all, but crossword constructors have never lacked conjuring up lesser-known animal species.

Nice job, puzzle-maker! Oh, and Ginny, too.
Am I the only one who thought (and types in) "Susan" at first, for title Madonna role?

I thought this was really tough for a Monday. Til I realize it wasn’t Monday. That’s what Monday holidays will do to me. Still took me longer than the average Tuesday. But who doesn’t enjoy a little Escher and badassery

Forrest, Jenny, and Forrest Jr. were like onions, celery, and green bell peppers.

My garden’s weeds are a hoe-ly terror.
Fun puzzle.

I was so hoping we would see

MALDEN
C
E
S
C
H
E
R

and we could retire Natick.

TIL---There are no lakes "about 120 miles south of London" (UK). 

While solving, I entered ERIE almost immediately, though I was a bit surprised for the London, Ontario trick to appear on a Tuesday. After finishing the puzzle, I used Google Earth to draw a circle of radius 120 miles around London, U.K. A sliver of Normandy lies within that circle south of London, but I failed to spot any lakes there. I did learn that there's an Aldi on Bd Suzanne Clément in Fécamp. (Sometimes the world seems very small nowadays.)

Seemed like a solid Tuesday puzzle, and perhaps a bit more challenging that usual for the day. MCESCHER and BADASSERY were certainly interesting.

And one again I spelled YACHT correctly on my first try.

Well.....Tuesday, after all.

The theme was nice enough; it's the rest of the puzzle that made us go BLEH (not even BLECH?)....
The only mystery was OCHER or OCHRE?

And I see the previous FAY, FEY, FAE, etc., were meant to soften us up for 22D.  You mean there are Other Species of FAE (aside, of course, from Bad Fairies and Good Fairy God-mothers)??

And that's about all the fun there was to be had here.
Didn't even try to link up COY (COYER? SRSLY??) and ARCH with identical clues for a bit of zing.

Plus it's raining AGAIN.

Long time since I had a personal Natick on Tuesday and had to run letters. I’m not complaining per se about Li Po (although maybe obscure for a Tuesday when there’s a more accessible option) and I probably should have guessed EPA but couldn’t get past “banner”. Bolt was new to me too. Again, not complaining, personally I like more of a challenge, just surprised for an early week puzzle.

Kept thinking it must be Wednesday... or if I'm really optimistic maybe it's Friday and I'm just super with it today. But, no, it  is alas but Tuesday, and Li Po created a black hole of ideas in that area of the puzzle for me. Thankful that the last vowel of FAE didn't cause more trouble. I'd written in FA because I thought it would be dicey, but the second half of 27A came together quite early to resolve that uncertainty.

Good fun---in my wheelhouse but with some good misdirection and head-scratching 
LI PO, in his peculiarly English transliteration, was a gimme---I remember him courtesy of Nicholas Freeling's joke about a poet made of Lithium and Polonium. And the crossing three-letter American organization is one of the few I know, and associate with the demise of DDT.
Winced a little at the "spreadable" BRIE, and the association of FAE with "species" and "folklore". The folkloric fairy folk come in many forms, and aren't called FAE.

Hung for the longest time over ERIE. I suspected London, Ontario, but the distance felt completely wrong, from my time living in that area---and it seems to be actually just wrong.
My only unknown was 65A---extra periods as OTS. Sport? High school?

So, yes, more like that please, but with slightly better fact- checking.
I kept trying to figure out if "Xing" was a Chinese app or social media site I hadn't heard of -- only at the very end did I clock it as X-ing or crossing

Regarding London and ERIE: it looks like the farthest ends of Lake ERIE (near Niagara falls to the east and Amherstburg to the west) are each about 120 miles from London, Ontario. So perhaps that is what the clue is referencing, not Lake ERIE at its closest point?

Quite the misdirection for a Tuesday.

An amazingly fun puzzle. TOSCA, ESCHER, and Lake ERIE in one grid? I felt as if I had come home. Not to mention the punny theme, and the bonus clever, misleading clues. And cheeeeese, Gromit! 

Too-too wonderful, Ginny. Let's see more from you soon!
Finished quickly with no lookups but the unholy popup popped up! Had to find and fix 2 typos.

Hard for a Tuesday. Maybe rather than "Poet written about in the Books of Tang," we could have had "Dumb surgery for the pudgy narcissist." And I've also never bolted anything down (except with actual bolts).

Lots of hate here for BLEH. Sometimes a constructor has to settle for a marginal word to avoid blowing up and reworking a whole sector of a puzzle, which can be a huge time suck. Constructing/editing is not as easy as some folks think it is.

Another morning of faëty! *** *** *** Lake Milton--in fact a reservoir along the Mahoning River, about 20 mi. east of Youngstown--is about 120 mi. due south of London, ON; but how am I supposed to fit that in without using a rebus? A rare instance of a genuine miscluing in the NYTXW. *** *** *** I loved seeing GEODE getting some love; I have two in my collection: a twinned double geode of amethyst, and one of celestite, of a lovely light blue. I once tried washing the celestite one, until I realized that the matrix, composed of limestone, was starting to dissolve. Since then, it's canned pressurized air dusting only. Slightly larger is the celestite geode on South Bass Island: https://putinbay.com/pib-activites/crystal-cave/ . It lies about 120 mi. southeast of London, ON, so maybe that's what the clue was getting at.

Just out of interest, how do the people who are complaining think BLEH shoud be spelt? 
I just wrote it straight in without a second thought.
meh.
As to 56 Down, altitude and elevation are not synonyms.

Strands!
No spoilers, plz, 'til after View All Replies

Got the spangram right off the bat, but do not know half the answers as such.

Strands #450
“A strange new world”
🟡🔵🔵🔵
🔵💡🔵💡
🔵
We are all so incredibly proud of you, DEB!!!!!

"Poet written about" is a bit weird instead of T'ang dynasty poet. It just makes the clue a tiny bit harder but not in a clever way. Oh well, not a major issue, but generally it was a hard solve for a Tuesday.

Once again, my undergrad major in East Asian Studies pays dividends, although I learned the Tang Dynasty poet as LI BO. He wrote lots of poems about getting drunk and getting into sword fights...my kind of guy! (H/T to John Ezra for posting a few) And who could forget the classic, "13 Ways of Looking at a Jug of Wine."

I may be wrong, but I think Opus the Penguin said BLEH to express disdain.

Great fun today and a record solve for me in just under 17 minutes.  One look up for the reflecting sphere artist. 
Maybe it’s the Englishness but bleh, bolt and Erie came easily - most because I’m 30 miles south of London, UK and I know there are no lakes further south as they’d be in the sea so I defaulted to my standard 4 letter lake answer. 
10/10
Li Po? Too obscure.

Some 70 years ago in an advanced placement English class in high school, I was introduced to 52D, Strunk and White’s “The Elements of Style.” I can’t recall that reference to it ever came up again, but today it came to mind in an instant. What do they say about long-term memory?
Absolutely hated this puzzle. Stopped 3/4 through as the material became more and more obscure and arcane

Tuesdays are so much harder than Mondays. I turned on Autocheck very early and still had to reveal four squares. Two for LIPO of course. Sometimes these clues feel like trivia for obscure definitions. Is it really common knowledge that BLIND is a noun for a duck hunting locale? DIET as a synonym for fare is a bit of a stretch. And “EPA” for DDT banner? I have no idea what this means.

With this difficulty, it took me about 19 min to solve. Compare this with yesterdays 5 min speedrun. I personally think the jump between Mon and Tue is too big

As CNS says before me, "Poet written about in the Books of Tang" -- who has even HEARD of that reference? -- for LIPO instead of "weight reduction procedure, informally" is just too much badassery for a Tuesday puzzle.  I liked the resst of it, though.
Loved the theme, hated the multiple obscure clues on a Tuesday.

A very challenging crossword for a Tuesday. A lot of obscure answers clustered together with poor cluing makes for a frustrating solve. 

1A Puccini heroine who “lived for art, lived for love”
2A Like the base-8 number system
3D Animal with chestnut-and-white fur

There is a good possibility many people have never heard of the answers and this makes a horrid solve.

No problems with this one until the west edge.  I’ve never heard of a duck BLIND, which is not the puzzle’s fault of course, but I still feel for a Tuesday puzzle a more conventional clue should have been given there, especially considering it is crossing the obscure LIPO and non-word BLEH.

A toughie (BADASSERY) for Tuesday, taking almost 30 minutes and a few obscure look-ups but I enjoyed the themed clues and got them almost straight away. 
Quite a jump from yesterday but I enjoy a challenge.
Random shout out here.  I'm a lifelong Cheap Trick fan and 57D really caught my eye.  They did a song called Auf wiedersehen and this clue brought back some good memories.
Got the theme without too much trouble but the fill was hard for an early week puzzle. Not bad per se, but not a good Tuesday.
1D's 'cell' really threw me off until I got a couple of crossing letters and realised that it was the American usage of cell, oof.
I can't believe no one has posted this yet. Here's la Diva Maria living for art, for love, for Sunday evenings: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ggywso5O9zw
I'm glad to see that many solvers found this puzzle tough! The clever theme helped me work out some of the more obscure clues.
I like this puzzle's pun. This is a fun way to make a puzzle. It's just as punny as wormholes, but doesn't break so many rules of crosswords as to be frustrating.

Saturday's too easy,
Tuesday's too hard;
This clue is cheesy,
That one's a bard.
considerably more pun/puzzle clues than the Tuesday norm made this a soooooooooolve.
Lake Erie is about 35 miles south of London, ON not 120…
[They mind the GAAP] is amazing. Why not include that?

I thoroughly enjoyed this punny puzzle!  It was just crunchy enough for my Tuesday taste. I really liked the clever wordplay and grinned throughout, especially after the clues landed.  Thanks for a fun puzzle Ginny.
Doesn't "Vissi d'Arte" literally mean "I lived *of* art", or "on" it?
How the hell are we supposed to guess "Eden" for the hint,  "Couple's first home?" Bloody ridiculous.
LIPO / EPA was a dirty, dirty cross even for the worst Saturday
I didn't like the americans.

Finished 10 minutes faster than my average but this was a bit BLEH 🤷‍♀️. 40A had me first with WOLF, then CHOW, then finally BOLT after filling in BRIE but that had me 🧐 I don’t consider it a gooey cheese? 🤷‍♀️ The rest went fairly quick - had 60A before the other theme clues 😬.
BLEH? LIPO? Really?
We were really just throwing junk against the wall with this one, huh?
I guess someone needs to make a gluttony puzzle now, because those (bleh?)  competitive eaters also wolf down their food.
BLEH is right…

Complaints about BLEH are unwarranted.  My mother had a whole catalog of sounds she made, mostly to avoid cursing (not allowed at home)—various clicks, hisses, mmmm's, nnnns, etc.  I found myself using them when I was at work and hit a snag, and had responses from raised eyebrows to "Wow, neat sound!" (the younger set).

I don't recall her ever saying BLEH, but I'm sure there was something similar at the ready.
Coasters are round, huh? My Pimpernels are rectangular.
The cross of Li Po with Holi Festival was a real nattick for me. n Yuck.  Add to the BLEH on the down and the puzzle is ruined.  Just a poorly construction section.

I was surprised to see so many negative comments. I thought this puzzle was a bit crunchy but lots of fun to figure out, with a very clever theme. Thanks Ginny Too. 
Guess I’ll weigh in on the BOLT controversy too. I was definitely familiar with that usage.
Count me among the people who enjoyed this one. It felt like a regular hard Tuesday/easy Wednesday puzzle to me.

“Don’t bolt your food!”  
                                  —  My Grandmother

Was trying to think of a Mercury astronaut with a last name of four letters for 33D. 

(I’ll show myself out now …)
Holy cow! I got it!

This was absolutely wonderful. A bit crunchier than most Tuesdays at first pass but I ended below my average - getting the theme helped me with the northwest quadrant- WHOLLYOWNED I thought was really nice. 

And any puzzle that mentions EB White is automatically awesome.

53D is wrong!! My boss is not a "Zoom meeting annoyance!!" Har!!

(Sorry, cracking myself up!!) 

She's the furthest thing from being any kind of annoyance but I can't wait to tell her that her name was the answer for Zoom annoyance. (But I will wait till after our big event tomorrow.) 

Though really, the biggest annoyance on Zoom is how five years later, people (sometimes including me) still can't manage to unmute themselves. 😆 

Anyhow, I see lots of people disliked this one but I thought it was ALLGOOD! The few things I didn't know off hand were accessible through crosses, even in the middle left area where, like others, I slowed a bit. 

I knew I knew BLIND but my brain couldn't access it until I set it down for a few hours (the puzzle, not my brain), and then it came right away. Not a fan of hunting but where I grew up, it was very common. Once I got BLIND, I was hunky dory. 

Really fun theme!!
I know BOLT, but had WOLF for way too long.
Yeah, seriously, The Books of Tang.....
This felt poorly constructed and unduly hard for a Tuesday :-/

LIPO / EPA was unduly annoying. sat there for 10 minutes trying to figure it out. I wasn’t sure about what DDT is, so I guessed related to dentistry and had BLAH and ADA. Books of Tang I’ve never heard of. Finished 9 mins slower than average. 

Rough Tuesday, but on a 5-day streak. I have yet to get to a 7-day no lookup streak, maybe I can do it this time!

As a Chinese-American, it took me so long to figure out the last clue - my first thought for Tang poet is Li Bai, but I could not for the life of me find the old-fashioned (colonial?) romanization until I ran through all the letters of the alphabet. Just a pet peeve of mine.

Fun puzzle otherwise! never heard of LI PO, but I love LI BAI’s poems

It's fascinating to me how many commenters seem to think that if they don't know of something, then that thing is obscure (i.e., not worth knowing?). If we started out that way as children, we'd never learn anything at all.

Yikes. This was a tough Tuesday. I lost half an hour trying to figure out the LIPO/EPA cross. Glad it wasn't just me. 

Oh well, on to Wednesday...

I gave up on this one and just turned on Autocheck because I was so confused. I’ve never heard of someone BOLTing down food (40D), and didn’t know there was a Lake Erie near London (regardless of whether it’s Ontario or England). So, I learned something new today! 

However, I do think the clueing for 33D/41A could have been more Tuesday-friendly as others have suggested (yes, it’s harder than Monday, but it’s still an early-week puzzle). It seemed more like a Friday or Saturday clue to me. But if LI PO shows up later this week, hopefully I’ll get it this time!

@john ezra

@john ezra You beat me to it. Here is a longer one A Poem of Changgan. It begins: My hair had hardly covered my forehead. I was picking flowers, playing by my door, When you, my lover, on a bamboo horse, Came trotting in circles and throwing green plums. We lived near together on a lane in Ch’ang-kan, Both of us young and happy-hearted. ...At fourteen I became your wife, So bashful that I dared not smile, And I lowered my head toward a dark corner And would not turn to your thousand calls; But at fifteen I straightened my brows and laughed, Learning that no dust could ever seal our love, That even unto death I would await you by my post And would never lose heart in the tower of silent watching. ...Then when I was sixteen, you left on a long journey Through the Gorges of Ch’u-t’ang, of rock and whirling water. . . The whole poem is here: https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems/56596/a-poem-of-changgan

@john ezra

This line made me shiver (in a good way): “We sit together, the mountain and me,

@Andrzej
A duck BLIND is a structure that people hunting ducks hide in or behind while waiting for the ducks to show up so they can shoot them.
RETOOL is a legitimate thing.
I don't know how other Americans eat Brie, but the people I know will let it age and then serve at room temperature so the insides are runny (gooey) and eat it, including the rind, on a cracker or a slice of baguette.

@Vaer

Thank you. I keep trying to think if I know what that sort of blind is called in Polish but nothing comes to me. Poland has its hunting lingo, of course, but I'm not familiar with it - few things are as alien to me as hunting. I just can't understand how anybody can possibly enjoy killing animals. I wish they would shoot back... I understand populations of some species need to be controlled for ecological reasons, but I still don't get why anybody would want to actually do the deed.

@Andrzej

I eat brie, with the rind, on warm French baguette.
But Président makes a spreadable brie, without the rind, perhaps only for the American market? 
It comes in a small tub, much like Philadelphia cream cheese.

@sotto voce

How can it even *be* brie without the rind? Ripening for weeks in its rind is an essential characteristic of brie, and so it would be considered false advertising to sell a non-rind-ripened cheese as brie over here. The cheese brand President is known in Poland, too, and they do sell a spreadable cream cheese, but it's not called brie (President-brand brie wedges cut from wheels, and small camembert wheels, both with rind, are available).

@Andrzej
I agree that spreadable brie in a tub sounds horrifying, but if you go to the President website, it is a thing they make and sell in the US.

@Andrzej
I actually forgot it's Tuesday and thought i was solving the Wednesday puzzle 🙃 😅

@Andrzej I too was startled by the word spread used to describe BRIE. The horror. Here I can get Brie de Meaux, an unpasteurized piece of heaven. Mmmmmm. A spread with no rind, there are hardly words...

@Andrzej Think about the old English name for that famous city: Peking, now Beijing. Transcription is tricky when the sounds don’t line up perfectly and also when there are multiple local dialects/languages involved.

See also Bombay/Mumbai where the same combo of influences were at play.

@Andrzej Sure, on a warm day you *can* spread Brie. But being able to spread something does not make it a spread!

Though as per your other replies, it seems that the supermarket Brie brand "Président" does in fact sell a "Créme de Brie" spread. 'The rich and creamy essence of brie without the rind', they say. Just don't tell the French.

@Tim The French say quelle horreur! Sacre bleu. (OK they don’t say that, but I do because it’s funny.) We have Présidente brand here (with the rind bien sûr), in the supermarket with other cheeses of desperation.

@Andrzej Americans eat American cheese a lot, including my wife. When she brings it into the home, I go, "Why???" But she likes it, even though it wouldn't even qualify as cheese in Europe. But we occasionally also eat BRIE. Baked brie is a common way to eat it, and since I don't like the taste of the rind, it works well for me, as I can avoid it. The brie is placed in an baking dish, and you heat the whole thing up until it is gooey. There is usually fruit on the top, notably figs, caramelized apples or pears, or berries. Served this way, brie is definitely a spread. https://entertainingwithbeth.com/baked-brie-with-fig-jam/

@Steve L

I mean, prepared a specific way, anything can be a spread, but sure, you do have a point: crossword clues are not definitions, and it's ok if they work on only some level. Still, clueing brie as a spread threw those who eat it the way its original makers intended, which is a bit bleh.

As Li Bai would put it:

I drink wine in the moonlight
And admire the morning dew
Baked brie melts before me
And I spread it on my crackers

@Andrzej

@Andrzej

@Andrzej

My point is that for many Americans, their first association to BRIE is in the baked, runny, gooey version; it's the Europeans who are more likely to eat it in solid form.  (Note:  that doesn't mean that many Americans don't eat it that way.)

@John
Do you believe every puzzle is constructed by the same person? Exactly who was being lazy here, and what should they have done differently?

John,

Don’t rock the yacht, I’m sleeping.

@John

Your comment is offbase in multiple ways.  

The word was in the exact center of today's puzzle; it was not in the center of yesterday's puzzle.

One day's puzzle has nothing to do with the next day's puzzle.

As Salvo pointed out, every puzzle is constructed by a different constructor.  I've never seen two in a row by the same constructor except for the week Patrick Blindauer produced the whole week with a unifying theme.

The two occurrences used different clues.

There's nothing here that is lazy.  When you use "lazy" in a criticism of a puzzle, there's a higher-than-99% chance you are not familiar with crossword construction.  And saying "super lazy" indicates more conviction on your part.

You may say that the editors are lazy for having run this puzzle after yesterday's, but believe me, no editor is going to put off a puzzle because it has the singular form of a word that was in the puzzle in the plural the day before.

@Nancy J.

@Nancy J. There was this small, artificial hill in the middle of our part of town when I was growing up. We sledded down it in winter and rode our bikes off the steepest slope in summer. At the foot of the hill there was an alley, not really a proper street: it only provided access to a small car park in the courtyard between two buildings. These were the 1980s, when few people owned a car. I once narrowly escaped death under the wheels of a Fiat: my friend's scream of CAAAR came when I was already going too fast to stop. Fun times. That's the spot as it looks now: https://maps.app.goo.gl/k5AcvuzBMjVQ2fzz5 And here are some pictures I took there in 1993: https://ursynow.org.pl/himki-i-wielka-przygoda/ The title photo was taken on the hill, and it is also in the background of the photo third to last. The dog was Max, a rescue who was with us 1989-2004. (the server for that website is really poor, so the article may take time to load, and a reload may be necessary if the pics don't show)

Nancy J. and all:

Road hockey memory for me. Move the nets, stand to the side leaning on sticks à la Ken Dryden, the adventurous holding their sticks low so the car’s tires would drive over the blade but not break it. If the “nets” were just two piles of snow, then build new ones if the car crushed any.

Time to go home soon if the car’s headlights were on.

@BB

There a a couple of workarounds to the problem of the View All Replies (VAR) button not being consistently displayed.  

One is to click the time/date stamp to the right of the poster's stated location.  This will "pop out" the thread from the list of all comments much the same way that if you use the link in the emailed notification when you post (same code).  One problem with this method is that to return to the main comment list you need to click on the Back To All Comments link which will take to to the top of the current comment list, not where you were when you isolated the thread in the first place. 

There is another method to trigger the display of the VAR button and hidden comments and that is to press the Recommend link which will refresh the the thread an display the VAR button, if there is one.  I've taken to "liking" all posts to see if there are additional comments.

@Ernest
The DDT ban may have been Before Your Time.  
When we were in Hawaii, stationed at Schofield Barracks (Oahu, up in the mountains where the humidity was less)--back in 1958-1960, big trucks drove through the streets of the post, emitting huge clouds of DDT so dense that the sun was blocked out for a while.  We raced around our quarters closing windows.  It was meant to quell the mosquito population, and it was a year-round practice.  God knows how much we inhaled, ingested, etc.  
The book _Silent Spring_ took a while to make a difference.

@MOL

@Anton  Literal translations don't always convey the understood meaning of a phrase in its native language. Case in point: while "I lived of art" may be the correct literal English translation of "vissi d'arte," it makes no sense. Accordingly, in the English translations of the Tosca libretto I've seen, "vissi d'arte" has always been translated to "I lived for art."

Shari,

I'm guessing that with the three-day weekend some of our fellow solvers were expecting a Monday puzzle.
@Barry Ancona That's not true for me. This is a tough Tuesday! Not complaining, but I came to the comments specifically to see if others thought it was a tough Tuesday.

@Shari Coats

I solved 16 seconds (or 4.4%) faster than my Tuesday average, and didn't find anything unusual about the difficulty level when I was solving.

The difficulty level is set to a solver who is familiar with the type of content found in the rest of the NYT and other literate sources.  (If you're not that kind of a person, you are on an uphill climb.)

So we understand [EPA banner] because:
a. we know what the EPA is,
b. we understand the punny meaning of "banner",
c. and we remember or know what it was that the EPA banned many years ago.

We know who LI PO was from either being familiar with his works, or merely because we've heard his name.

We know what a STOAT is and that the giveaway in the clue is the white fur.

We somehow know that duck hunters hide in a duck BLIND while hunting, even though we may never have done so ourselves.

Also, rather than blaming the puzzle if we're not at this level yet, we learn from every answer we don't know and get better and better every time.

There are still new things that I learn by solving puzzles.  But I can always solve by using the crosses, or by inferring the missing letters using our knowledge base (e.g. House of Tang points to a Chinese--or at least East Asian--answer for LI PO).

If you go through the week expecting every clue and answer to be like [Pet that meows]/CAT, you're going to be complaining a lot.
